query: When managing pastureland for natural pest control, is it better to delay mowing/grazing or to use grazing instead of cutting?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, both delayed mowing/grazing and using grazing instead of cutting have mixed effects on natural pest control in pastureland. For delayed mowing/grazing, action 727 shows that one replicated, randomised, controlled study found fewer predatory spiders with delayed cutting, while three studies from the UK found no change in insect predator numbers and one replicated study from Sweden found mixed effects between different predator groups. One of two replicated, randomised, controlled studies found more pest insects in late-cut plots and one found no effect. For using grazing instead of cutting, action 885 indicates that two studies from Australia and the UK found grazing instead of cutting had mixed effects on natural enemies, with some species and groups affected on some dates but not others, while one replicated study from New Zealand found no effect. Regarding pests, one of five studies found more pests when using grazing instead of cutting, and two studies found effects varied between pest groups and sampling dates, while two studies found no effect on pests. One randomised study found more ryegrass shoots were attacked by pests when grazing was used instead of cutting. The evidence suggests neither approach consistently provides superior natural pest control, with effects varying by species, timing, and location.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "pastureland management natural pest control mowing grazing"}

Ten studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of using rotational mowing. Two studies were in each of the USA, the Czech Republic and Switzerland, and one was in each of the UK, Germany, Europe and Japan.

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the Czech Republic found that grasslands managed with “mixed management”, which included mowing parts of a site at different times and leaving some areas uncut, had a similar community composition of butterflies, but a different community composition of moths, to grasslands managed by complete annual mowing.
Richness/diversity (6 studies): Three of four replicated studies (including two paired, controlled studies and two site comparison studies) in Germany, Switzerland, Japan and the Czech Republic found that grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years, by mowing and burning one half of the meadow each year, or by mowing parts of a site at different times and leaving some areas uncut, had a greater species richness and diversity of butterflies than grasslands cut in full once/year. However, one of these studies also found that grasslands managed by mowing parts of a site at different times and leaving some areas uncut had a lower species richness of moths than grasslands cut in full once/year. The fourth study found that grasslands managed by leaving a rotational area uncut on each mow had a similar species richness of butterflies and burnet moths to grasslands cut in full twice/year. One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that rotationally managed grasslands, including some rotationally mown grasslands, which were last managed longer ago had a higher species richness of butterflies than more recently managed grasslands. One replicated, site comparison study in Switzerland found that farms managed with more in-field agri-environment scheme (AES) options, including staggered mowing dates, had a similar species richness of butterflies to farms with fewer AES options.

POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (7 studies): Two replicated, paired, controlled studies (including one randomized study) in Germany and Switzerland found that grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years, or by leaving a rotational area uncut on each mow, had a higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths than grasslands cut in full once or twice per year. One of two replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that rotationally managed grasslands, including some rotationally mown grasslands, which were last managed longer ago had a higher abundance of butterflies than more recently managed grasslands. The other study found that rotationally mown grasslands had a lower abundance of butterflies in the second year after they were last cut than in the first year after mowing. One replicated, site comparison study in the UK reported that two heath fritillary populations survived on rotationally mown grasslands while six populations went extinct on unmanaged grasslands. One review in Europe reported that rotationally mowing grassland benefitted 27 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern. One replicated, site comparison study in Switzerland found that farms managed with more in-field agri-environment scheme (AES) options, including staggered mowing dates, had a similar abundance of butterflies to farms with fewer AES options.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Use (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the Czech Republic found that 29 out of 32 butterfly species preferred meadows which were half mown in June and August to meadows cut in full twice/year. The other three species were woodland species which only visited meadows temporarily."

query: What are the overall effects of altering pesticide application strategies to benefit natural enemies?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, altering pesticide application strategies can have several effects on natural enemies. Altering the timing of insecticide use resulted in more natural enemies when insecticides were sprayed earlier rather than later in the growing season (Action 723). Using pesticides only when pests or crop damage reach threshold levels increased numbers of natural enemies in two of three years, though effects lasted for as little as three weeks (Action 750). Additionally, threshold-based spraying regimes resulted in fewer pesticide applications being needed (Action 750). Delaying herbicide use led to more natural enemies, though some but not all natural enemy groups benefited and fewer groups benefited early in the season (Action 774). Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests, though effects on natural enemy populations were not monitored (Action 726). Using mass-emergence devices to increase natural enemy populations resulted in higher parasitism at one site but no effect at another site in urban areas (Action 775).

query: When planting non-crop vegetation to enhance natural pest control, what is the comparative evidence for planting new hedges versus plants that attract natural enemies with chemicals?
relevant_summary:
For growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals that attract natural enemies, four studies from China, Germany, India and Kenya tested this approach (Action 724). Three studies found higher numbers of natural enemies in plots with plants that produce attractive chemicals, with all four studies finding a decrease in either pest population or pest damage. One replicated, randomised, controlled study found an increase in crop yield in plots with plants that produce attractive chemicals (Action 724). Studies tested this approach on lettuce, orange, safflower and sorghum crops (Action 724).

For planting new hedges, evidence shows more mixed results (Action 752). One randomised, replicated, controlled study from China found no effect on spiders in crops when comparing plots with and without hedges. Studies from France and China found varying effects - one found more natural enemies in hedges than in adjacent crops while another found this effect varied between crop types, hedge species and years. Two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from France and Kenya found natural enemy abundance in hedges was affected by the type of hedge shrub/tree planted, with effects varying between natural enemy groups (Action 752). For pest control, one study from Kenya found effects on nematodes varied between different nematode groups (Action 752). Crops studied for hedge interventions were barley, beans, maize and wheat (Action 752).

Additional evidence from France and the UK showed newly planted hedges had higher abundance, species richness or diversity of beetles or spiders than crop fields or field margins, with a literature review finding lower pest outbreaks in areas with new hedges (Action 538). However, effectiveness varied between different hedge plant species (Action 538).

query: What are the potential negative impacts on crops when incorporating plant remains into the soil to control weeds?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, incorporating plant remains into soil for weed control can have several potential negative impacts on crops. Two of three studies found that crop growth was inhibited by allelopathic plant remains, though this could be minimized by changing the timing of application (Action 728). The timing of residue application is critical, as one study found that residues applied too far in advance of crop planting had the reverse effect on weed control, suggesting potential negative impacts on the intended crop as well (Action 728). Three randomized, replicated, controlled studies that compared yields in amended plots with weeded controls found positive, negative and mixed effects, indicating that incorporating plant remains can sometimes reduce crop yields (Action 728). The effectiveness and potential negative impacts varied between years, weed groups, crop species, and the type of residue used (Action 728). One study specifically found that the effects varied between years (Action 728), suggesting that environmental conditions can influence whether the impacts are positive or negative for crops.

One found higher carbon levels when straw was applied along with NPK fertilizers. One also found larger soil aggregates. One replicated study from China and the Philippines found mixed results depending on site.
Yield: One replicated trial from Denmark found higher barley yield when straw was incorporated. One trial from the Philippines found higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season.
 
Soil types covered: clay, clay loam, fine loam, loam/sandy loam, loamy sand, sandy, sandy clay loam, sandy loam, sandy-silt, silt loam, silty, silty-clay."

query: What actions can be taken to control weeds on farmland without relying on herbicides?
relevant_summary: Several non-herbicide methods for controlling weeds on farmland are supported by research evidence. Growing cover crops in arable fields can reduce weeds, with four replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Israel and Italy finding fewer weeds in plots with cover crops compared to plots without them (Action 1394). Growing plants that compete with damaging weeds is effective, with nine studies from Australia, Slovakia, the UK and the USA finding reduced weed plant weight or ground cover when planting competitive species, and five studies finding that competition reduced weed reproduction, survival or both (Action 722). Converting to organic farming provides weed control through non-chemical methods, with three randomized, replicated, controlled studies from the USA finding more weeds in organically farmed fields but demonstrating that organic methods can manage weeds without herbicides (Action 717). Reducing tillage affects weed populations, with studies finding increased numbers of some weeds and/or weed species under reduced tillage compared to conventional management (Action 126). Physical weed control methods are documented, including cutting which was found effective for controlling weeds like creeping thistle, and long-term grazing control which achieved effective weed management (Action 123). Manual harvesting or hand-weeding is referenced as a physical control method, though specific effectiveness evidence for farmland applications was not found (Action 1575). These methods provide farmers with multiple non-herbicide options for managing weeds while maintaining crop productivity.

{"query_string": "mechanical weed control cultivation organic farming methods"}

  "action_id": "126",
  "action_title": "Reduce tillage",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

A total of 42 individual studies (including seven replicated, controlled and randomized studies and six reviews) from Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Switzerland and the UK investigated the effects of reducing tillage on farmland wildlife. Thirty-four studies (of which 21 were replicated and controlled and seven also randomized, and five reviews) from nine European countries found some positive effects on earthworms, some invertebrates (other than earthworms), weeds or farmland birds, of reducing tillage compared to conventional management. Positive effects included increased biomass, species richness or abundance of earthworms, greater abundance of some invertebrates other than earthworms, increased numbers of some weeds and/or weed species, higher Eurasian skylark nest density, earlier laying date and shorter foraging distances on reduced tillage fields, and greater abundance of some birds - including Eurasian skylark, seed-eating songbirds and gamebirds in late winter on non-inversion or conservation tillage. A review found tillage had negative effects on invertebrate numbers and no-till systems had more invertebrate bird food resources.
Twenty-six studies (of which 13 replicated and controlled and three also randomized, and five reviews) from nine European countries found reducing tillage had either negative, no effect or no consistent effects on abundance, biomass, or species richness of some invertebrates (other than earthworms), earthworm abundance, biomass, or species richness, number of different plant species found as seeds, number of some weed species, mammal abundance, some bird species, and one study found bird preferences for conservation tillage fields decreased over time. Two studies found that crop type affected the number of weeds under different tillage regimes.
One small replicated trial in the UK compared bird numbers under two different forms of reduced tillage, and found more birds from species that make up the ‘Farmland Bird Index’ on broadcast than non-inversion tillage fields.
Two studies looked at the long-term effects of reduced tillage on earthworms (after ten years). One study found higher earthworm biomass under reduced tillage, the other study found earthworm abundance was the same between conventional and reduced tillage plots.
Three of the studies mentioned above did not distinguish between the effects of reducing tillage and reduced pesticide and/or fertilizer inputs."
}

Converting to organic farming provides weed control through non-chemical methods, with three randomized, replicated, controlled studies from the USA finding more weeds in organically farmed fields but demonstrating that organic methods can manage weeds without herbicides (Action 717). Physical weed control methods are documented, including cutting which was found effective for controlling weeds like creeping thistle, and long-term grazing control which achieved effective weed management (Action 123). Manual harvesting or hand-weeding is referenced as a physical control method, though specific effectiveness evidence for farmland applications was not found (Action 1575). query: To provide refuge for natural enemies, what is the comparative evidence for creating beetle banks versus leaving part of a crop unharvested?
relevant_summary:
For beetle banks as refuges for natural enemies, six studies from Canada, the UK and USA found that predators increased in adjacent crops according to a review, though effects varied with time in some studies and one study found no effect (Action 729). Four studies and a review found more invertebrate predators on beetle banks than in surrounding crops, but effects varied with time in some cases (Action 729). Eight studies from the UK and USA compared numbers of predatory invertebrates on beetle banks with other refuge habitats, with mixed results: two studies found more natural enemies on beetle banks, one review found similar or higher numbers, and four studies found similar or lower numbers (Action 729). Two studies found small or slow movements of predators from banks to crops, and one study found greater beetle activity in fields but this did not improve pest predation (Action 729).

For leaving part of crops unharvested as refuges for natural enemies, eight studies from Australia, Germany, Hungary, New Zealand, Switzerland and the USA tested this approach (Action 725). Three studies including one replicated controlled trial found an increase in abundance of predatory insects or spiders in the crop field or pasture that was partly uncut, while four studies including three replicated controlled trials found more predators in the unharvested or unmown area itself (Action 725). Two studies found that the ratio of predators to pests was higher in partially cut plots and one study found the same result in the uncut area (Action 725). One replicated controlled study from Australia found an increase in predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs in unharvested strips (Action 725). However, effects on pests were mixed, with some studies finding decreases and others finding increases in pest numbers in partially cut plots (Action 725).

query: What are the potential economic outcomes of adopting organic farming or alley cropping systems?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, the economic outcomes of organic farming and alley cropping systems include both yield and profit considerations. For organic farming, six randomised, replicated, controlled studies measured yields and found one positive effect, one negative effect and one mixed effect, plus no or inconsistent effects in three studies (Action 717). One study found net profit increased if produce received a premium, but otherwise profit decreased, while another study found a negative or no effect on profit (Action 717). For alley cropping systems, one controlled study from the USA found lower yield and one study from the Philippines reported similar or lower yields (Action 718). Additionally, one study from the USA found lower costs but also lower profit in alley cropped plots (Action 718). The economic viability of organic farming appears to be dependent on premium pricing for organic produce, while alley cropping systems may reduce production costs but also reduce overall profitability due to lower yields.

query: Which interventions are most effective for increasing pest parasitism rates?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, several interventions have shown effectiveness for increasing pest parasitism rates. Push-pull cropping systems that combine trap and repellent crops have demonstrated clear benefits, with two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from Kenya finding that these systems increased parasitism of stem borer larvae (action 753). Mass-emergence devices used in urban areas showed mixed results, with one randomised, replicated, controlled study in Switzerland finding higher parasitism at one site but no effect at another site (action 775). Excluding ants that protect pests can enhance parasitism, as one of two replicated, controlled studies from Japan and the USA found greater parasitism of pests by natural enemies when ants were excluded from trees, though another study found greater parasitism at only one site with no effect at another (action 886). Alley cropping systems showed variable effects on parasitism, with two of four studies from Kenya and the USA finding that effects varied between study sites, sampling dates, pest life stages or the width of crop alleys, while two studies found no effect on parasitism (action 718). One intervention specifically addresses incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use, with one controlled study from New Zealand finding this approach resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests (action 726). Flower strips and wildflower plantings were found to benefit invertebrates generally, with 50 out of 65 individual studies reporting positive effects on invertebrates including increased abundance and species richness, though specific parasitism rate effects were not detailed (action 442).

A total of 80 individual studies have in some way investigated the effects of flowering strips on biodiversity. Sixty-four individual studies show some benefits to one or more wildlife groups.


Sixty-five individual studies reported the effects of flower strips on invertebrates. Of these, fifty reported positive effects. Forty-one studies from eight European countries (including five reviews and twenty-three replicated controlled studies, of which one randomized and two site comparisons) found evidence that flower strips had a positive influence on invertebrate numbers with increased abundance, species richness/diversity, or both. Ten studies (nine replicated of which two controlled) found invertebrates visited or foraged on flower strips but did not specify increases/decreases in numbers. Two studies found effects on ground beetles other than changes in numbers. One replicated controlled study showed that ground beetles were more active or had enhanced feeding/reproductive conditions in flower strips. A review found flower strips supported ground beetle species that were rarely found in crops. Fifteen studies reported mixed or negative effects of flower strips on invertebrates. Six studies found no significant effects.


Twenty-one studies looked at the effects of flower strips on plants. Sixteen studies from seven European countries (including ten replicated controlled studies of which one randomized) found evidence that flower strips had higher plant cover, number of flowers, diversity, and species richness. One review found flower strips benefited plants but did not specify how. Four studies found negative or no effects of flower strips on the number or diversity of plant species. Five studies described the effects of different margin establishment or management techniques on plants.


Seven studies investigated birds and wildflower strips. Four replicated, controlled studies from Switzerland and the UK (two of which were randomized) and one review of European studies found evidence that plots sown with a wildflower or legume seed mix had a positive influence on birds. Flower strips attracted more birds or bird species and the number of birds using flower strips increased over time. Eurasian skylarks preferentially foraged in, and nested in or near, sown weed patches and were less likely to abandon their territories when they included sown weed patches. However one replicated trial in Switzerland found barn owls avoided sown wildflower areas. Two winter recording periods of the same replicated, controlled study in the UK found there were not more bird species or individuals on wildflower plots compared to control margins.


All five studies investigating the effects of wildflower strips on small mammals (four replicated studies from Switzerland and one review of studies from north-western Europe) found evidence that small mammals benefit from strips sown with wildflowers or flowers rich in pollen and nectar, with increases in abundance, density and species richness. One replicated study from Switzerland reported that most common vole home ranges and core regions of their territories were found within a wildflower strip.


Nineteen studies (of which eight replicated, controlled) reported positive effects on biodiversity of sowing specific plant species including phacelia, and/or other plant species such as borage and red clover. Three replicated studies (two also controlled) found negative impacts or no effects on biodiversity of sowing phacelia."

query: For pasture management in the UK, what is the comparative evidence on natural enemy abundance when delaying mowing versus using grazing instead of cutting?
relevant_summary:
For delaying mowing in UK pasture management, evidence shows mixed effects on natural enemy abundance. Action 727 reports that one replicated, randomised, controlled study found fewer predatory spiders with delayed cutting, while three UK studies (two replicated, randomised and controlled) found no change in insect predator numbers. A Swedish replicated study found mixed effects between different predator groups. Action 131 found that delaying mowing dates resulted in greater abundance of some spiders and ground beetles in some cases, but six studies from multiple countries including the UK found no clear effect on abundance of some insects and spiders.

For using grazing instead of cutting, Action 885 reports that two studies (one before-and-after and one replicated trial) from Australia and the UK found grazing instead of cutting had mixed effects on natural enemies, with some species and groups affected on some dates but not others. One replicated study from New Zealand found no effect on natural enemies when using grazing instead of cutting.

The evidence indicates that both delayed mowing and grazing instead of cutting show inconsistent effects on natural enemy abundance, with results varying by species, study location, timing, and specific natural enemy groups studied.

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of manipulating field structure by adding linear features like hedges, beetle banks, or alley cropping?
relevant_summary:
Evidence for the effectiveness of manipulating field structure with linear features shows mixed but generally positive results across multiple taxa and agricultural contexts. For beetle banks, studies demonstrate enhanced biodiversity benefits including higher densities of harvest mouse nests compared to field margins (Action ID: 2393), and increased abundance of micro-moths compared to conventionally managed field margins (Action ID: 3927). Beetle banks support more invertebrate predators than surrounding crops, though effects varied with time, and reviews found that predators increased in adjacent crops with potential economic savings if they prevented pests from reaching spray thresholds or causing 5% yield loss (Action ID: 729).

For hedges, evidence shows established hedgerows had higher species richness of butterflies and macro-moths than in-field beetle banks, crops or pasture in studies from the UK, Ireland and Canada (Action ID: 3976). Newly planted hedges had higher abundance, species richness or diversity of beetles or spiders than crop fields or field margins, with newly established hedges supporting more ground beetles than older hedges (Action ID: 538). However, natural enemy abundance in hedges was affected by the type of hedge shrub/tree planted (Action ID: 752).

Alley cropping showed variable effectiveness, with studies finding that effects on parasitism varied between study sites, sampling dates, pest life stages or crop alley width, and mixed effects on pest populations - two of four studies found more pests in alley cropped plots while one found fewer pests (Action ID: 718). One study found intercropping with trees resulted in higher diversity of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (Action ID: 903).

Grass buffer strips and field margins demonstrated consistent benefits for butterflies and moths, with wider grass margins (up to 6m wide) having greater species richness or diversity than narrower margins, and floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips having higher abundance of butterflies than standard grass margins (Action ID: 3982). Field studies found more positive population trends and higher populations for some bird species at sites with grass margins (Action ID: 191).

query: What actions are available to a farmer growing perennial crops to enhance natural enemy populations on the ground versus in the tree canopy?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, farmers growing perennial crops have several distinct approaches to enhance natural enemy populations at ground level versus in tree canopies.

**Ground-level actions** include allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops (Action 720), which studies found increased natural enemies on the ground in some cases, though effects varied between natural enemy groups. Creating beetle banks (Action 729) provides refuges for invertebrate predators, with studies showing more natural enemies on beetle banks than in surrounding crops. Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards or vineyards (Action 1395) was found by multiple studies to increase natural enemy numbers in some or all comparisons, though effects varied. Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies (Action 724) showed increased natural enemy numbers in plots with attractive plants. Planting new hedges (Action 752) can support natural enemies, though effects varied between hedge species and natural enemy groups.

**Canopy-focused actions** include isolating colonies of beneficial ants (Action 773), where one study found predatory ants occupied more cashew trees when colonies were kept isolated. Excluding ants that protect pests (Action 886) affects natural enemies in tree canopies, with studies showing effects varied between natural enemy species and groups. Using chemicals to attract natural enemies (Action 754) can be applied in canopy systems, with some studies finding increased natural enemies though effects varied between enemy groups and sites.

**Combined ground and canopy approaches** include diversifying ground vegetation and canopy structure in habitat around woody crops (Action 3526), which affects the overall ecosystem supporting natural enemies. Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops (Action 720) was found to affect natural enemies both on the ground and in crop tree or vine canopies, though results varied between studies.
